Thou didst not know on't. Who comes here? O heavens,
If you do love old men, if your sweet sway
Allow obedience, if yourselves are old,
Make it your cause; send down, and take my part!
Art not ashamed to look upon this beard?
O Regan, wilt thou take her by the hand?

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Why not by the hand, sir? How have I offended?
All's not offence that indiscretion finds
And dotage terms so.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: O sides, you are too tough;
Will you yet hold? How came my man i' the stocks?

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: I set him there, sir: but his own disorders
Deserved much less advancement.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: You! did you?

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: I pray you, father, being weak, seem so.
If, till the expiration of your month,
You will return and sojourn with my sister,
Dismissing half your train, come then to me:
I am now from home, and out of that provision
Which shall be needful for your entertainment.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Return to her, and fifty men dismiss'd?
No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose
To wage against the enmity o' the air;
To be a comrade with the wolf and owl,--
Necessity's sharp pinch! Return with her?
Why, the hot-blooded France, that dowerless took
Our youngest born, I could as well be brought
To knee his throne, and, squire-like; pension beg
To keep base life afoot. Return with her?
Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter
To this detested groom.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: At your choice, sir.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad:
I will not trouble thee, my child; farewell:
We'll no more meet, no more see one another:
But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter;
Or rather a disease that's in my flesh,
Which I must needs call mine: thou art a boil,
A plague-sore, an embossed carbuncle,
In my corrupted blood. But I'll not chide thee;
Let shame come when it will, I do not call it:
I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot,
Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove:
Mend when thou canst; be better at thy leisure:
I can be patient; I can stay with Regan,
I and my hundred knights.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Not altogether so:
I look'd not for you yet, nor am provided
For your fit welcome. Give ear, sir, to my sister;
For those that mingle reason with your passion
Must be content to think you old, and so--
But she knows what she does.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Is this well spoken?

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: I dare avouch it, sir: what, fifty followers?
Is it not well? What should you need of more?
Yea, or so many, sith that both charge and danger
Speak 'gainst so great a number? How, in one house,
Should many people, under two commands,
Hold amity? 'Tis hard; almost impossible.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Why might not you, my lord, receive attendance
From those that she calls servants or from mine?

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Why not, my lord? If then they chanced to slack you,
We could control them. If you will come to me,--
For now I spy a danger,--I entreat you
To bring but five and twenty: to no more
Will I give place or notice.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: I gave you all--

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: And in good time you gave it.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Made you my guardians, my depositaries;
But kept a reservation to be follow'd
With such a number. What, must I come to you
With five and twenty, Regan? said you so?

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: And speak't again, my lord; no more with me.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Those wicked creatures yet do look well-favour'd,
When others are more wicked: not being the worst
Stands in some rank of praise.
I'll go with thee:
Thy fifty yet doth double five and twenty,
And thou art twice her love.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Hear me, my lord;
What need you five and twenty, ten, or five,
To follow in a house where twice so many
Have a command to tend you?

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: What need one?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: O, reason not the need: our basest beggars
Are in the poorest thing superfluous:
Allow not nature more than nature needs,
Man's life's as cheap as beast's: thou art a lady;
If only to go warm were gorgeous,
Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear'st,
Which scarcely keeps thee warm. But, for true need,--
You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need!
You see me here, you gods, a poor old man,
As full of grief as age; wretched in both!
If it be you that stir these daughters' hearts
Against their father, fool me not so much
To bear it tamely; touch me with noble anger,
And let not women's weapons, water-drops,
Stain my man's cheeks! No, you unnatural hags,
I will have such revenges on you both,
That all the world shall--I will do such things,--
What they are, yet I know not: but they shall be
The terrors of the earth. You think I'll weep
No, I'll not weep:
I have full cause of weeping; but this heart
Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws,
Or ere I'll weep. O fool, I shall go mad!

section.para: Exeunt KING LEAR, GLOUCESTER, KENT, and Fool

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Let us withdraw; 'twill be a storm.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: This house is little: the old man and his people
Cannot be well bestow'd.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: 'Tis his own blame; hath put himself from rest,
And must needs taste his folly.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: For his particular, I'll receive him gladly,
But not one follower.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: So am I purposed.
Where is my lord of Gloucester?

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Follow'd the old man forth: he is return'd.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: The king is in high rage.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Whither is he going?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: He calls to horse; but will I know not whither.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: 'Tis best to give him way; he leads himself.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: My lord, entreat him by no means to stay.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Alack, the night comes on, and the bleak winds
Do sorely ruffle; for many miles about
There's scarce a bush.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: O, sir, to wilful men,
The injuries that they themselves procure
Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors:
He is attended with a desperate train;
And what they may incense him to, being apt
To have his ear abused, wisdom bids fear.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Shut up your doors, my lord; 'tis a wild night:
My Regan counsels well; come out o' the storm.

section.title: SCENE I. A heath.
section.para: Storm still. Enter KENT and a Gentleman, meeting

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Who's there, besides foul weather?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: One minded like the weather, most unquietly.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: I know you. Where's the king?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Contending with the fretful element:
Bids the winds blow the earth into the sea,
Or swell the curled water 'bove the main,
That things might change or cease; tears his white hair,
Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage,
Catch in their fury, and make nothing of;
Strives in his little world of man to out-scorn
The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain.
This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch,
The lion and the belly-pinched wolf
Keep their fur dry, unbonneted he runs,
And bids what will take all.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: But who is with him?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: None but the fool; who labours to out-jest
His heart-struck injuries.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Sir, I do know you;
And dare, upon the warrant of my note,
Commend a dear thing to you. There is division,
Although as yet the face of it be cover'd
With mutual cunning, 'twixt Albany and Cornwall;
Who have--as who have not, that their great stars
Throned and set high?--servants, who seem no less,
Which are to France the spies and speculations
Intelligent of our state; what hath been seen,
Either in snuffs and packings of the dukes,
Or the hard rein which both of them have borne
Against the old kind king; or something deeper,
Whereof perchance these are but furnishings;
But, true it is, from France there comes a power
Into this scatter'd kingdom; who already,
Wise in our negligence, have secret feet
In some of our best ports, and are at point
To show their open banner. Now to you:
If on my credit you dare build so far
To make your speed to Dover, you shall find
Some that will thank you, making just report
Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow
The king hath cause to plain.
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding;
And, from some knowledge and assurance, offer
This office to you.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: I will talk further with you.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: No, do not.
For confirmation that I am much more
Than my out-wall, open this purse, and take
What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia,--
As fear not but you shall,--show her this ring;
And she will tell you who your fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm!
I will go seek the king.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Give me your hand: have you no more to say?

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Few words, but, to effect, more than all yet;
That, when we have found the king,--in which your pain
That way, I'll this,--he that first lights on him
Holla the other.

section.title: SCENE II. Another part of the heath. Storm still.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! rage! blow!
You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout
Till you have drench'd our steeples, drown'd the cocks!
You sulphurous and thought-executing fires,
Vaunt-couriers to oak-cleaving thunderbolts,
Singe my white head! And thou, all-shaking thunder,
Smite flat the thick rotundity o' the world!
Crack nature's moulds, an germens spill at once,
That make ingrateful man!

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: O nuncle, court holy-water in a dry
house is better than this rain-water out o' door.
Good nuncle, in, and ask thy daughters' blessing:
here's a night pities neither wise man nor fool.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! spout, rain!
Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire, are my daughters:
I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness;
I never gave you kingdom, call'd you children,
You owe me no subscription: then let fall
Your horrible pleasure: here I stand, your slave,
A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man:
But yet I call you servile ministers,
That have with two pernicious daughters join'd
Your high engender'd battles 'gainst a head
So old and white as this. O! O! 'tis foul!

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: He that has a house to put's head in has a good
head-piece.
The cod-piece that will house
Before the head has any,
The head and he shall louse;
So beggars marry many.
The man that makes his toe
What he his heart should make
Shall of a corn cry woe,
And turn his sleep to wake.
For there was never yet fair woman but she made
mouths in a glass.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: No, I will be the pattern of all patience;
I will say nothing.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Who's there?

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: Marry, here's grace and a cod-piece; that's a wise
man and a fool.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Alas, sir, are you here? things that love night
Love not such nights as these; the wrathful skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the dark,
And make them keep their caves: since I was man,
Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder,
Such groans of roaring wind and rain, I never
Remember to have heard: man's nature cannot carry
The affliction nor the fear.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Let the great gods,
That keep this dreadful pother o'er our heads,
Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch,
That hast within thee undivulged crimes,
Unwhipp'd of justice: hide thee, thou bloody hand;
Thou perjured, and thou simular man of virtue
That art incestuous: caitiff, to pieces shake,
That under covert and convenient seeming
Hast practised on man's life: close pent-up guilts,
Rive your concealing continents, and cry
These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man
More sinn'd against than sinning.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Alack, bare-headed!
Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel;
Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest:
Repose you there; while I to this hard house--
More harder than the stones whereof 'tis raised;
Which even but now, demanding after you,
Denied me to come in--return, and force
Their scanted courtesy.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: My wits begin to turn.
Come on, my boy: how dost, my boy? art cold?
I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my fellow?
The art of our necessities is strange,
That can make vile things precious. Come,
your hovel.
Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart
That's sorry yet for thee.

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: He that has and a little tiny wit--
With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,--
Must make content with his fortunes fit,
For the rain it raineth every day.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: True, my good boy. Come, bring us to this hovel.

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: This is a brave night to cool a courtezan.
I'll speak a prophecy ere I go:
When priests are more in word than matter;
When brewers mar their malt with water;
When nobles are their tailors' tutors;
No heretics burn'd, but wenches' suitors;
When every case in law is right;
No squire in debt, nor no poor knight;
When slanders do not live in tongues;
Nor cutpurses come not to throngs;
When usurers tell their gold i' the field;
And bawds and whores do churches build;
Then shall the realm of Albion
Come to great confusion:
Then comes the time, who lives to see't,
That going shall be used with feet.
This prophecy Merlin shall make; for I live before his time.

section.title: SCENE III. Gloucester's castle.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Alack, alack, Edmund, I like not this unnatural
dealing. When I desire their leave that I might
pity him, they took from me the use of mine own
house; charged me, on pain of their perpetual
displeasure, neither to speak of him, entreat for
him, nor any way sustain him.

linegroup.speaker: EDMUND
linegroup.line: Most savage and unnatural!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Go to; say you nothing. There's a division betwixt
the dukes; and a worse matter than that: I have
received a letter this night; 'tis dangerous to be
spoken; I have locked the letter in my closet:
these injuries the king now bears will be revenged
home; there's part of a power already footed: we
must incline to the king. I will seek him, and
privily relieve him: go you and maintain talk with
the duke, that my charity be not of him perceived:
if he ask for me. I am ill, and gone to bed.
Though I die for it, as no less is threatened me,
the king my old master must be relieved. There is
some strange thing toward, Edmund; pray you, be careful.

linegroup.speaker: EDMUND
linegroup.line: This courtesy, forbid thee, shall the duke
Instantly know; and of that letter too:
This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me
That which my father loses; no less than all:
The younger rises when the old doth fall.

section.title: SCENE IV. The heath. Before a hovel.
section.para: Enter KING LEAR, KENT, and Fool

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Here is the place, my lord; good my lord, enter:
The tyranny of the open night's too rough
For nature to endure.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Let me alone.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Good my lord, enter here.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Wilt break my heart?

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: I had rather break mine own. Good my lord, enter.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm
Invades us to the skin: so 'tis to thee;
But where the greater malady is fix'd,
The lesser is scarce felt. Thou'ldst shun a bear;
But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea,
Thou'ldst meet the bear i' the mouth. When the
mind's free,
The body's delicate: the tempest in my mind
Doth from my senses take all feeling else
Save what beats there. Filial ingratitude!
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For lifting food to't? But I will punish home:
No, I will weep no more. In such a night
To shut me out! Pour on; I will endure.
In such a night as this! O Regan, Goneril!
Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all,--
O, that way madness lies; let me shun that;
No more of that.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Good my lord, enter here.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Prithee, go in thyself: seek thine own ease:
This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
On things would hurt me more. But I'll go in.
In, boy; go first. You houseless poverty,--
Nay, get thee in. I'll pray, and then I'll sleep.
Poor naked wretches, whereso'er you are,
That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,
How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides,
Your loop'd and window'd raggedness, defend you
From seasons such as these? O, I have ta'en
Too little care of this! Take physic, pomp;
Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,
That thou mayst shake the superflux to them,
And show the heavens more just.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Within Fathom and half, fathom and half! Poor Tom!

section.para: The Fool runs out from the hovel

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: Come not in here, nuncle, here's a spirit
Help me, help me!

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Give me thy hand. Who's there?

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: A spirit, a spirit: he says his name's poor Tom.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: What art thou that dost grumble there i' the straw?
Come forth.

section.para: Enter EDGAR disguised as a mad man

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Away! the foul fiend follows me!
Through the sharp hawthorn blows the cold wind.
Hum! go to thy cold bed, and warm thee.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Hast thou given all to thy two daughters?
And art thou come to this?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Who gives any thing to poor Tom? whom the foul
fiend hath led through fire and through flame, and
through ford and whirlipool e'er bog and quagmire;
that hath laid knives under his pillow, and halters
in his pew; set ratsbane by his porridge; made film
proud of heart, to ride on a bay trotting-horse over
four-inched bridges, to course his own shadow for a
traitor. Bless thy five wits! Tom's a-cold,--O, do
de, do de, do de. Bless thee from whirlwinds,
star-blasting, and taking! Do poor Tom some
charity, whom the foul fiend vexes: there could I
have him now,--and there,--and there again, and there.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: What, have his daughters brought him to this pass?
Couldst thou save nothing? Didst thou give them all?

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: Nay, he reserved a blanket, else we had been all shamed.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Now, all the plagues that in the pendulous air
Hang fated o'er men's faults light on thy daughters!

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: He hath no daughters, sir.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Death, traitor! nothing could have subdued nature
To such a lowness but his unkind daughters.
Is it the fashion, that discarded fathers
Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?
Judicious punishment! 'twas this flesh begot
Those pelican daughters.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Pillicock sat on Pillicock-hill:
Halloo, halloo, loo, loo!

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: This cold night will turn us all to fools and madmen.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Take heed o' the foul fiend: obey thy parents;
keep thy word justly; swear not; commit not with
man's sworn spouse; set not thy sweet heart on proud
array. Tom's a-cold.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: What hast thou been?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: A serving-man, proud in heart and mind; that curled
my hair; wore gloves in my cap; served the lust of
my mistress' heart, and did the act of darkness with
her; swore as many oaths as I spake words, and
broke them in the sweet face of heaven: one that
slept in the contriving of lust, and waked to do it:
wine loved I deeply, dice dearly: and in woman
out-paramoured the Turk: false of heart, light of
ear, bloody of hand; hog in sloth, fox in stealth,
wolf in greediness, dog in madness, lion in prey.
Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of
silks betray thy poor heart to woman: keep thy foot
out of brothels, thy hand out of plackets, thy pen
from lenders' books, and defy the foul fiend.
Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind:
Says suum, mun, ha, no, nonny.
Dolphin my boy, my boy, sessa! let him trot by.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer
with thy uncovered body this extremity of the skies.
Is man no more than this? Consider him well. Thou
owest the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the sheep
no wool, the cat no perfume. Ha! here's three on
's are sophisticated! Thou art the thing itself:
unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor bare,
forked animal as thou art. Off, off, you lendings!
come unbutton here.

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: Prithee, nuncle, be contented; 'tis a naughty night
to swim in. Now a little fire in a wild field were
like an old lecher's heart; a small spark, all the
rest on's body cold. Look, here comes a walking fire.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet: he begins
at curfew, and walks till the first cock; he gives
the web and the pin, squints the eye, and makes the
hare-lip; mildews the white wheat, and hurts the
poor creature of earth.
S. Withold footed thrice the old;
He met the night-mare, and her nine-fold;
Bid her alight,
And her troth plight,
And, aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: How fares your grace?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: What's he?

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Who's there? What is't you seek?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What are you there? Your names?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Poor Tom; that eats the swimming frog, the toad,
the tadpole, the wall-newt and the water; that in
the fury of his heart, when the foul fiend rages,
eats cow-dung for sallets; swallows the old rat and
the ditch-dog; drinks the green mantle of the
standing pool; who is whipped from tithing to
tithing, and stock- punished, and imprisoned; who
hath had three suits to his back, six shirts to his
body, horse to ride, and weapon to wear;
But mice and rats, and such small deer,
Have been Tom's food for seven long year.
Beware my follower. Peace, Smulkin; peace, thou fiend!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What, hath your grace no better company?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: The prince of darkness is a gentleman:
Modo he's call'd, and Mahu.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Our flesh and blood is grown so vile, my lord,
That it doth hate what gets it.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Poor Tom's a-cold.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Go in with me: my duty cannot suffer
To obey in all your daughters' hard commands:
Though their injunction be to bar my doors,
And let this tyrannous night take hold upon you,
Yet have I ventured to come seek you out,
And bring you where both fire and food is ready.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: First let me talk with this philosopher.
What is the cause of thunder?

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Good my lord, take his offer; go into the house.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: I'll talk a word with this same learned Theban.
What is your study?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: How to prevent the fiend, and to kill vermin.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Let me ask you one word in private.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Importune him once more to go, my lord;
His wits begin to unsettle.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Canst thou blame him?
His daughters seek his death: ah, that good Kent!
He said it would be thus, poor banish'd man!
Thou say'st the king grows mad; I'll tell thee, friend,
I am almost mad myself: I had a son,
Now outlaw'd from my blood; he sought my life,
But lately, very late: I loved him, friend;
No father his son dearer: truth to tell thee,
The grief hath crazed my wits. What a night's this!
I do beseech your grace,--

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: O, cry your mercy, sir.
Noble philosopher, your company.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Tom's a-cold.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: In, fellow, there, into the hovel: keep thee warm.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Come let's in all.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: This way, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: With him;
I will keep still with my philosopher.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Good my lord, soothe him; let him take the fellow.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Take him you on.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Sirrah, come on; go along with us.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Come, good Athenian.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: No words, no words: hush.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Child Rowland to the dark tower came,
His word was still,--Fie, foh, and fum,
I smell the blood of a British man.

section.title: SCENE V. Gloucester's castle.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: I will have my revenge ere I depart his house.

linegroup.speaker: EDMUND
linegroup.line: How, my lord, I may be censured, that nature thus
gives way to loyalty, something fears me to think
of.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: I now perceive, it was not altogether your
brother's evil disposition made him seek his death;
but a provoking merit, set a-work by a reprovable
badness in himself.

linegroup.speaker: EDMUND
linegroup.line: How malicious is my fortune, that I must repent to
be just! This is the letter he spoke of, which
approves him an intelligent party to the advantages
of France: O heavens! that this treason were not,
or not I the detector!

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: o with me to the duchess.

linegroup.speaker: EDMUND
linegroup.line: If the matter of this paper be certain, you have
mighty business in hand.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: True or false, it hath made thee earl of
Gloucester. Seek out where thy father is, that he
may be ready for our apprehension.

linegroup.speaker: EDMUND
linegroup.line: Aside If I find him comforting the king, it will
stuff his suspicion more fully.--I will persevere in
my course of loyalty, though the conflict be sore
between that and my blood.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: I will lay trust upon thee; and thou shalt find a
dearer father in my love.

section.title: SCENE VI. A chamber in a farmhouse adjoining the castle.
section.para: Enter GLOUCESTER, KING LEAR, KENT, Fool, and EDGAR

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Here is better than the open air; take it
thankfully. I will piece out the comfort with what
addition I can: I will not be long from you.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: All the power of his wits have given way to his
impatience: the gods reward your kindness!

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Frateretto calls me; and tells me
Nero is an angler in the lake of darkness.
Pray, innocent, and beware the foul fiend.

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: Prithee, nuncle, tell me whether a madman be a
gentleman or a yeoman?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: A king, a king!

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: No, he's a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son;
for he's a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman
before him.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: To have a thousand with red burning spits
Come hissing in upon 'em,--

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: The foul fiend bites my back.

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: He's mad that trusts in the tameness of a wolf, a
horse's health, a boy's love, or a whore's oath.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: It shall be done; I will arraign them straight.
Come, sit thou here, most learned justicer;
Thou, sapient sir, sit here. Now, you she foxes!

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Look, where he stands and glares!
Wantest thou eyes at trial, madam?
Come o'er the bourn, Bessy, to me,--

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: Her boat hath a leak,
And she must not speak
Why she dares not come over to thee.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: The foul fiend haunts poor Tom in the voice of a
nightingale. Hopdance cries in Tom's belly for two
white herring. Croak not, black angel; I have no
food for thee.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: How do you, sir? Stand you not so amazed:
Will you lie down and rest upon the cushions?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: I'll see their trial first. Bring in the evidence.
Thou robed man of justice, take thy place;
And thou, his yoke-fellow of equity,
Bench by his side:
you are o' the commission,
Sit you too.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Let us deal justly.
Sleepest or wakest thou, jolly shepherd?
Thy sheep be in the corn;
And for one blast of thy minikin mouth,
Thy sheep shall take no harm.
Pur! the cat is gray.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Arraign her first; 'tis Goneril. I here take my
oath before this honourable assembly, she kicked the
poor king her father.

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: Come hither, mistress. Is your name Goneril?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: She cannot deny it.

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: Cry you mercy, I took you for a joint-stool.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: And here's another, whose warp'd looks proclaim
What store her heart is made on. Stop her there!
Arms, arms, sword, fire! Corruption in the place!
False justicer, why hast thou let her 'scape?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Bless thy five wits!

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: O pity! Sir, where is the patience now,
That thou so oft have boasted to retain?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Aside My tears begin to take his part so much,
They'll mar my counterfeiting.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: The little dogs and all, Tray, Blanch, and
Sweet-heart, see, they bark at me.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Tom will throw his head at them. Avaunt, you curs!
Be thy mouth or black or white,
Tooth that poisons if it bite;
Mastiff, grey-hound, mongrel grim,
Hound or spaniel, brach or lym,
Or bobtail tike or trundle-tail,
Tom will make them weep and wail:
For, with throwing thus my head,
Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.
Do de, de, de. Sessa! Come, march to wakes and
fairs and market-towns. Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Then let them anatomize Regan; see what breeds
about her heart. Is there any cause in nature that
makes these hard hearts?
You, sir, I entertain for one of my hundred; only I
do not like the fashion of your garments: you will
say they are Persian attire: but let them be changed.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Make no noise, make no noise; draw the curtains:
so, so, so. We'll go to supper i' he morning. So, so, so.

linegroup.speaker: Fool
linegroup.line: And I'll go to bed at noon.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Come hither, friend: where is the king my master?

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Here, sir; but trouble him not, his wits are gone.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Good friend, I prithee, take him in thy arms;
I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him:
There is a litter ready; lay him in 't,
And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet
Both welcome and protection. Take up thy master:
If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life,
With thine, and all that offer to defend him,
Stand in assured loss: take up, take up;
And follow me, that will to some provision
Give thee quick conduct.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Oppressed nature sleeps:
This rest might yet have balm'd thy broken senses,
Which, if convenience will not allow,
Stand in hard cure.
Come, help to bear thy master;
Thou must not stay behind.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Come, come, away.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: When we our betters see bearing our woes,
We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
Who alone suffers suffers most i' the mind,
Leaving free things and happy shows behind:
But then the mind much sufferance doth o'er skip,
When grief hath mates, and bearing fellowship.
How light and portable my pain seems now,
When that which makes me bend makes the king bow,
He childed as I father'd! Tom, away!
Mark the high noises; and thyself bewray,
When false opinion, whose wrong thought defiles thee,
In thy just proof, repeals and reconciles thee.
What will hap more to-night, safe 'scape the king!
Lurk, lurk.

section.title: SCENE VII. Gloucester's castle.
section.para: Enter CORNWALL, REGAN, GONERIL, EDMUND, and Servants

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Post speedily to my lord your husband; show him
this letter: the army of France is landed. Seek
out the villain Gloucester.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Hang him instantly.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Pluck out his eyes.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund, keep you our
sister company: the revenges we are bound to take
upon your traitorous father are not fit for your
beholding. Advise the duke, where you are going, to
a most festinate preparation: we are bound to the
like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent
betwixt us. Farewell, dear sister: farewell, my
lord of Gloucester.
How now! where's the king?

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: My lord of Gloucester hath convey'd him hence:
Some five or six and thirty of his knights,
Hot questrists after him, met him at gate;
Who, with some other of the lords dependants,
Are gone with him towards Dover; where they boast
To have well-armed friends.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Get horses for your mistress.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Farewell, sweet lord, and sister.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Edmund, farewell.
Go seek the traitor Gloucester,
Pinion him like a thief, bring him before us.
Though well we may not pass upon his life
Without the form of justice, yet our power
Shall do a courtesy to our wrath, which men
May blame, but not control. Who's there? the traitor?

section.para: Enter GLOUCESTER, brought in by two or three

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Ingrateful fox! 'tis he.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Bind fast his corky arms.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What mean your graces? Good my friends, consider
You are my guests: do me no foul play, friends.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Bind him, I say.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Hard, hard. O filthy traitor!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Unmerciful lady as you are, I'm none.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: To this chair bind him. Villain, thou shalt find--

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: By the kind gods, 'tis most ignobly done
To pluck me by the beard.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: So white, and such a traitor!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Naughty lady,
These hairs, which thou dost ravish from my chin,
Will quicken, and accuse thee: I am your host:
With robbers' hands my hospitable favours
You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Come, sir, what letters had you late from France?

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Be simple answerer, for we know the truth.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: And what confederacy have you with the traitors
Late footed in the kingdom?

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: To whose hands have you sent the lunatic king? Speak.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: I have a letter guessingly set down,
Which came from one that's of a neutral heart,
And not from one opposed.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Cunning.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: And false.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Where hast thou sent the king?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: To Dover.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charged at peril--

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Wherefore to Dover? Let him first answer that.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: I am tied to the stake, and I must stand the course.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Wherefore to Dover, sir?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Because I would not see thy cruel nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister
In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.
The sea, with such a storm as his bare head
In hell-black night endured, would have buoy'd up,
And quench'd the stelled fires:
Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.
If wolves had at thy gate howl'd that stern time,
Thou shouldst have said 'Good porter, turn the key,'
All cruels else subscribed: but I shall see
The winged vengeance overtake such children.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: See't shalt thou never. Fellows, hold the chair.
Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: He that will think to live till he be old,
Give me some help! O cruel! O you gods!

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: One side will mock another; the other too.

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: If you see vengeance,--

linegroup.speaker: First Servant
linegroup.line: Hold your hand, my lord:
I have served you ever since I was a child;
But better service have I never done you
Than now to bid you hold.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: How now, you dog!

linegroup.speaker: First Servant
linegroup.line: If you did wear a beard upon your chin,
I'd shake it on this quarrel. What do you mean?

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: My villain!

linegroup.speaker: First Servant
linegroup.line: Nay, then, come on, and take the chance of anger.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Give me thy sword. A peasant stand up thus!

section.para: Takes a sword, and runs at him behind

linegroup.speaker: First Servant
linegroup.line: O, I am slain! My lord, you have one eye left
To see some mischief on him. O!

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: Lest it see more, prevent it. Out, vile jelly!
Where is thy lustre now?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: All dark and comfortless. Where's my son Edmund?
Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of nature,
To quit this horrid act.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Out, treacherous villain!
Thou call'st on him that hates thee: it was he
That made the overture of thy treasons to us;
Who is too good to pity thee.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: O my follies! then Edgar was abused.
Kind gods, forgive me that, and prosper him!

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell
His way to Dover.
How is't, my lord? how look you?

linegroup.speaker: CORNWALL
linegroup.line: I have received a hurt: follow me, lady.
Turn out that eyeless villain; throw this slave
Upon the dunghill. Regan, I bleed apace:
Untimely comes this hurt: give me your arm.

linegroup.speaker: Second Servant
linegroup.line: I'll never care what wickedness I do,
If this man come to good.

linegroup.speaker: Third Servant
linegroup.line: If she live long,
And in the end meet the old course of death,
Women will all turn monsters.

linegroup.speaker: Second Servant
linegroup.line: Let's follow the old earl, and get the Bedlam
To lead him where he would: his roguish madness
Allows itself to any thing.

linegroup.speaker: Third Servant
linegroup.line: Go thou: I'll fetch some flax and whites of eggs
To apply to his bleeding face. Now, heaven help him!

section.title: SCENE I. The heath.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Yet better thus, and known to be contemn'd,
Than still contemn'd and flatter'd. To be worst,
The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune,
Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear:
The lamentable change is from the best;
The worst returns to laughter. Welcome, then,
Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!
The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst
Owes nothing to thy blasts. But who comes here?
linegroup.para: Enter GLOUCESTER, led by an Old Man
linegroup.line: My father, poorly led? World, world, O world!
But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,
Lie would not yield to age.

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: O, my good lord, I have been your tenant, and
your father's tenant, these fourscore years.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Away, get thee away; good friend, be gone:
Thy comforts can do me no good at all;
Thee they may hurt.

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: Alack, sir, you cannot see your way.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes;
I stumbled when I saw: full oft 'tis seen,
Our means secure us, and our mere defects
Prove our commodities. O dear son Edgar,
The food of thy abused father's wrath!
Might I but live to see thee in my touch,
I'ld say I had eyes again!

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: How now! Who's there?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Aside O gods! Who is't can say 'I am at
the worst'?
I am worse than e'er I was.

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: 'Tis poor mad Tom.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Aside And worse I may be yet: the worst is not
So long as we can say 'This is the worst.'

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: Fellow, where goest?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Is it a beggar-man?

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: Madman and beggar too.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: He has some reason, else he could not beg.
I' the last night's storm I such a fellow saw;
Which made me think a man a worm: my son
Came then into my mind; and yet my mind
Was then scarce friends with him: I have heard
more since.
As flies to wanton boys, are we to the gods.
They kill us for their sport.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Aside How should this be?
Bad is the trade that must play fool to sorrow,
Angering itself and others.--Bless thee, master!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Is that the naked fellow?

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: Ay, my lord.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Then, prithee, get thee gone: if, for my sake,
Thou wilt o'ertake us, hence a mile or twain,
I' the way toward Dover, do it for ancient love;
And bring some covering for this naked soul,
Who I'll entreat to lead me.

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: Alack, sir, he is mad.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: 'Tis the times' plague, when madmen lead the blind.
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure;
Above the rest, be gone.

linegroup.speaker: Old Man
linegroup.line: I'll bring him the best 'parel that I have,
Come on't what will.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Sirrah, naked fellow,--

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Poor Tom's a-cold.
I cannot daub it further.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Come hither, fellow.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Aside And yet I must.--Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Know'st thou the way to Dover?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Both stile and gate, horse-way and foot-path. Poor
Tom hath been scared out of his good wits: bless
thee, good man's son, from the foul fiend! five
fiends have been in poor Tom at once; of lust, as
Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness; Mahu, of
stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of
mopping and mowing, who since possesses chambermaids
and waiting-women. So, bless thee, master!

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Here, take this purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues
Have humbled to all strokes: that I am wretched
Makes thee the happier: heavens, deal so still!
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,
That slaves your ordinance, that will not see
Because he doth not feel, feel your power quickly;
So distribution should undo excess,
And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Ay, master.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: There is a cliff, whose high and bending head
Looks fearfully in the confined deep:
Bring me but to the very brim of it,
And I'll repair the misery thou dost bear
With something rich about me: from that place
I shall no leading need.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Give me thy arm:
Poor Tom shall lead thee.

section.title: SCENE II. Before ALBANY's palace.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Welcome, my lord: I marvel our mild husband
Not met us on the way.
Now, where's your master'?

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Madam, within; but never man so changed.
I told him of the army that was landed;
He smiled at it: I told him you were coming:
His answer was 'The worse:' of Gloucester's treachery,
And of the loyal service of his son,
When I inform'd him, then he call'd me sot,
And told me I had turn'd the wrong side out:
What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him;
What like, offensive.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: To EDMUND Then shall you go no further.
It is the cowish terror of his spirit,
That dares not undertake: he'll not feel wrongs
Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way
May prove effects. Back, Edmund, to my brother;
Hasten his musters and conduct his powers:
I must change arms at home, and give the distaff
Into my husband's hands. This trusty servant
Shall pass between us: ere long you are like to hear,
If you dare venture in your own behalf,
A mistress's command. Wear this; spare speech;
Decline your head: this kiss, if it durst speak,
Would stretch thy spirits up into the air:
Conceive, and fare thee well.

linegroup.speaker: EDMUND
linegroup.line: Yours in the ranks of death.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: My most dear Gloucester!
O, the difference of man and man!
To thee a woman's services are due:
My fool usurps my body.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Madam, here comes my lord.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: I have been worth the whistle.

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: O Goneril!
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face. I fear your disposition:
That nature, which contemns its origin,
Cannot be border'd certain in itself;
She that herself will sliver and disbranch
From her material sap, perforce must wither
And come to deadly use.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: No more; the text is foolish.

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile:
Filths savour but themselves. What have you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what have you perform'd?
A father, and a gracious aged man,
Whose reverence even the head-lugg'd bear would lick,
Most barbarous, most degenerate! have you madded.
Could my good brother suffer you to do it?
A man, a prince, by him so benefited!
If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
Send quickly down to tame these vile offences,
It will come,
Humanity must perforce prey on itself,
Like monsters of the deep.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Milk-liver'd man!
That bear'st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs;
Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning
Thine honour from thy suffering; that not know'st
Fools do those villains pity who are punish'd
Ere they have done their mischief. Where's thy drum?
France spreads his banners in our noiseless land;
With plumed helm thy slayer begins threats;
Whiles thou, a moral fool, sit'st still, and criest
'Alack, why does he so?'

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: See thyself, devil!
Proper deformity seems not in the fiend
So horrid as in woman.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: O vain fool!

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: Thou changed and self-cover'd thing, for shame,
Be-monster not thy feature. Were't my fitness
To let these hands obey my blood,
They are apt enough to dislocate and tear
Thy flesh and bones: howe'er thou art a fiend,
A woman's shape doth shield thee.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Marry, your manhood now--

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: What news?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: O, my good lord, the Duke of Cornwall's dead:
Slain by his servant, going to put out
The other eye of Gloucester.

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: Gloucester's eye!

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: A servant that he bred, thrill'd with remorse,
Opposed against the act, bending his sword
To his great master; who, thereat enraged,
Flew on him, and amongst them fell'd him dead;
But not without that harmful stroke, which since
Hath pluck'd him after.

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: This shows you are above,
You justicers, that these our nether crimes
So speedily can venge! But, O poor Gloucester!
Lost he his other eye?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: Both, both, my lord.
This letter, madam, craves a speedy answer;
'Tis from your sister.

linegroup.speaker: GONERIL
linegroup.line: Aside One way I like this well;
But being widow, and my Gloucester with her,
May all the building in my fancy pluck
Upon my hateful life: another way,
The news is not so tart.--I'll read, and answer.

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: Where was his son when they did take his eyes?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: Come with my lady hither.

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: He is not here.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: No, my good lord; I met him back again.

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: Knows he the wickedness?

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: Ay, my good lord; 'twas he inform'd against him;
And quit the house on purpose, that their punishment
Might have the freer course.

linegroup.speaker: ALBANY
linegroup.line: Gloucester, I live
To thank thee for the love thou show'dst the king,
And to revenge thine eyes. Come hither, friend:
Tell me what more thou know'st.

section.title: SCENE III. The French camp near Dover.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back
know you the reason?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Something he left imperfect in the
state, which since his coming forth is thought
of; which imports to the kingdom so much
fear and danger, that his personal return was
most required and necessary.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Who hath he left behind him general?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: The Marshal of France, Monsieur La Far.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Did your letters pierce the queen to any
demonstration of grief?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Ay, sir; she took them, read them in my presence;
And now and then an ample tear trill'd down
Her delicate cheek: it seem'd she was a queen
Over her passion; who, most rebel-like,
Sought to be king o'er her.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: O, then it moved her.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Not to a rage: patience and sorrow strove
Who should express her goodliest. You have seen
Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears
Were like a better way: those happy smilets,
That play'd on her ripe lip, seem'd not to know
What guests were in her eyes; which parted thence,
As pearls from diamonds dropp'd. In brief,
Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved,
If all could so become it.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Made she no verbal question?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: 'Faith, once or twice she heaved the name of 'father'
Pantingly forth, as if it press'd her heart:
Cried 'Sisters! sisters! Shame of ladies! sisters!
Kent! father! sisters! What, i' the storm? i' the night?
Let pity not be believed!' There she shook
The holy water from her heavenly eyes,
And clamour moisten'd: then away she started
To deal with grief alone.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: It is the stars,
The stars above us, govern our conditions;
Else one self mate and mate could not beget
Such different issues. You spoke not with her since?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: No.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Was this before the king return'd?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: No, since.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Well, sir, the poor distressed Lear's i' the town;
Who sometime, in his better tune, remembers
What we are come about, and by no means
Will yield to see his daughter.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Why, good sir?

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: A sovereign shame so elbows him: his own unkindness,
That stripp'd her from his benediction, turn'd her
To foreign casualties, gave her dear rights
To his dog-hearted daughters, these things sting
His mind so venomously, that burning shame
Detains him from Cordelia.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Alack, poor gentleman!

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Of Albany's and Cornwall's powers you heard not?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: 'Tis so, they are afoot.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Well, sir, I'll bring you to our master Lear,
And leave you to attend him: some dear cause
Will in concealment wrap me up awhile;
When I am known aright, you shall not grieve
Lending me this acquaintance. I pray you, go
Along with me.

section.title: SCENE IV. The same. A tent.
section.para: Enter, with drum and colours, CORDELIA, Doctor, and Soldiers

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: Alack, 'tis he: why, he was met even now
As mad as the vex'd sea; singing aloud;
Crown'd with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds,
With bur-docks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers,
Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow
In our sustaining corn. A century send forth;
Search every acre in the high-grown field,
And bring him to our eye.
What can man's wisdom
In the restoring his bereaved sense?
He that helps him take all my outward worth.

linegroup.speaker: Doctor
linegroup.line: There is means, madam:
Our foster-nurse of nature is repose,
The which he lacks; that to provoke in him,
Are many simples operative, whose power
Will close the eye of anguish.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: All blest secrets,
All you unpublish'd virtues of the earth,
Spring with my tears! be aidant and remediate
In the good man's distress! Seek, seek for him;
Lest his ungovern'd rage dissolve the life
That wants the means to lead it.

linegroup.speaker: Messenger
linegroup.line: News, madam;
The British powers are marching hitherward.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: 'Tis known before; our preparation stands
In expectation of them. O dear father,
It is thy business that I go about;
Therefore great France
My mourning and important tears hath pitied.
No blown ambition doth our arms incite,
But love, dear love, and our aged father's right:
Soon may I hear and see him!

section.title: SCENE V. Gloucester's castle.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: But are my brother's powers set forth?

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Ay, madam.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Himself in person there?

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Madam, with much ado:
Your sister is the better soldier.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Lord Edmund spake not with your lord at home?

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: No, madam.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: What might import my sister's letter to him?

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: I know not, lady.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: 'Faith, he is posted hence on serious matter.
It was great ignorance, Gloucester's eyes being out,
To let him live: where he arrives he moves
All hearts against us: Edmund, I think, is gone,
In pity of his misery, to dispatch
His nighted life: moreover, to descry
The strength o' the enemy.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: I must needs after him, madam, with my letter.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Our troops set forth to-morrow: stay with us;
The ways are dangerous.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: I may not, madam:
My lady charged my duty in this business.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you
Transport her purposes by word? Belike,
Something--I know not what: I'll love thee much,
Let me unseal the letter.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Madam, I had rather--

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: I know your lady does not love her husband;
I am sure of that: and at her late being here
She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks
To noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: I, madam?

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: I speak in understanding; you are; I know't:
Therefore I do advise you, take this note:
My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk'd;
And more convenient is he for my hand
Than for your lady's: you may gather more.
If you do find him, pray you, give him this;
And when your mistress hears thus much from you,
I pray, desire her call her wisdom to her.
So, fare you well.
If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor,
Preferment falls on him that cuts him off.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Would I could meet him, madam! I should show
What party I do follow.

linegroup.speaker: REGAN
linegroup.line: Fare thee well.

section.title: SCENE VI. Fields near Dover.
section.para: Enter GLOUCESTER, and EDGAR dressed like a peasant

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: When shall we come to the top of that same hill?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: You do climb up it now: look, how we labour.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Methinks the ground is even.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Horrible steep.
Hark, do you hear the sea?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: No, truly.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect
By your eyes' anguish.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: So may it be, indeed:
Methinks thy voice is alter'd; and thou speak'st
In better phrase and matter than thou didst.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: You're much deceived: in nothing am I changed
But in my garments.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Methinks you're better spoken.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Come on, sir; here's the place: stand still. How fearful
And dizzy 'tis, to cast one's eyes so low!
The crows and choughs that wing the midway air
Show scarce so gross as beetles: half way down
Hangs one that gathers samphire, dreadful trade!
Methinks he seems no bigger than his head:
The fishermen, that walk upon the beach,
Appear like mice; and yond tall anchoring bark,
Diminish'd to her cock; her cock, a buoy
Almost too small for sight: the murmuring surge,
That on the unnumber'd idle pebbles chafes,
Cannot be heard so high. I'll look no more;
Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight
Topple down headlong.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Set me where you stand.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Give me your hand: you are now within a foot
Of the extreme verge: for all beneath the moon
Would I not leap upright.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Let go my hand.
Here, friend, 's another purse; in it a jewel
Well worth a poor man's taking: fairies and gods
Prosper it with thee! Go thou farther off;
Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Now fare you well, good sir.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: With all my heart.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Why I do trifle thus with his despair
Is done to cure it.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Kneeling O you mighty gods!
This world I do renounce, and, in your sights,
Shake patiently my great affliction off:
If I could bear it longer, and not fall
To quarrel with your great opposeless wills,
My snuff and loathed part of nature should
Burn itself out. If Edgar live, O, bless him!
Now, fellow, fare thee well.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Gone, sir: farewell.
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The treasury of life, when life itself
Yields to the theft: had he been where he thought,
By this, had thought been past. Alive or dead?
Ho, you sir! friend! Hear you, sir! speak!
Thus might he pass indeed: yet he revives.
What are you, sir?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Away, and let me die.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air,
So many fathom down precipitating,
Thou'dst shiver'd like an egg: but thou dost breathe;
Hast heavy substance; bleed'st not; speak'st; art sound.
Ten masts at each make not the altitude
Which thou hast perpendicularly fell:
Thy life's a miracle. Speak yet again.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: But have I fall'n, or no?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: From the dread summit of this chalky bourn.
Look up a-height; the shrill-gorged lark so far
Cannot be seen or heard: do but look up.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Alack, I have no eyes.
Is wretchedness deprived that benefit,
To end itself by death? 'Twas yet some comfort,
When misery could beguile the tyrant's rage,
And frustrate his proud will.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Give me your arm:
Up: so. How is 't? Feel you your legs? You stand.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Too well, too well.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: This is above all strangeness.
Upon the crown o' the cliff, what thing was that
Which parted from you?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: A poor unfortunate beggar.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: As I stood here below, methought his eyes
Were two full moons; he had a thousand noses,
Horns whelk'd and waved like the enridged sea:
It was some fiend; therefore, thou happy father,
Think that the clearest gods, who make them honours
Of men's impossibilities, have preserved thee.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: I do remember now: henceforth I'll bear
Affliction till it do cry out itself
'Enough, enough,' and die. That thing you speak of,
I took it for a man; often 'twould say
'The fiend, the fiend:' he led me to that place.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Bear free and patient thoughts. But who comes here?
linegroup.para: Enter KING LEAR, fantastically dressed with wild flowers
linegroup.line: The safer sense will ne'er accommodate
His master thus.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: No, they cannot touch me for coining; I am the
king himself.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: O thou side-piercing sight!

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Nature's above art in that respect. There's your
press-money. That fellow handles his bow like a
crow-keeper: draw me a clothier's yard. Look,
look, a mouse! Peace, peace; this piece of toasted
cheese will do 't. There's my gauntlet; I'll prove
it on a giant. Bring up the brown bills. O, well
flown, bird! i' the clout, i' the clout: hewgh!
Give the word.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Sweet marjoram.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Pass.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: I know that voice.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Ha! Goneril, with a white beard! They flattered
me like a dog; and told me I had white hairs in my
beard ere the black ones were there. To say 'ay'
and 'no' to every thing that I said!--'Ay' and 'no'
too was no good divinity. When the rain came to
wet me once, and the wind to make me chatter; when
the thunder would not peace at my bidding; there I
found 'em, there I smelt 'em out. Go to, they are
not men o' their words: they told me I was every
thing; 'tis a lie, I am not ague-proof.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: The trick of that voice I do well remember:
Is 't not the king?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Ay, every inch a king:
When I do stare, see how the subject quakes.
I pardon that man's life. What was thy cause? Adultery?
Thou shalt not die: die for adultery! No:
The wren goes to 't, and the small gilded fly
Does lecher in my sight.
Let copulation thrive; for Gloucester's bastard son
Was kinder to his father than my daughters
Got 'tween the lawful sheets.
To 't, luxury, pell-mell! for I lack soldiers.
Behold yond simpering dame,
Whose face between her forks presages snow;
That minces virtue, and does shake the head
To hear of pleasure's name;
The fitchew, nor the soiled horse, goes to 't
With a more riotous appetite.
Down from the waist they are Centaurs,
Though women all above:
But to the girdle do the gods inherit,
Beneath is all the fiends';
There's hell, there's darkness, there's the
sulphurous pit,
Burning, scalding, stench, consumption; fie,
fie, fie! pah, pah! Give me an ounce of civet,
good apothecary, to sweeten my imagination:
there's money for thee.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: O, let me kiss that hand!

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Let me wipe it first; it smells of mortality.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: O ruin'd piece of nature! This great world
Shall so wear out to nought. Dost thou know me?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: I remember thine eyes well enough. Dost thou squiny
at me? No, do thy worst, blind Cupid! I'll not
love. Read thou this challenge; mark but the
penning of it.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Were all the letters suns, I could not see one.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: I would not take this from report; it is,
And my heart breaks at it.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Read.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What, with the case of eyes?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: O, ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your
head, nor no money in your purse? Your eyes are in
a heavy case, your purse in a light; yet you see how
this world goes.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: I see it feelingly.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: What, art mad? A man may see how this world goes
with no eyes. Look with thine ears: see how yond
justice rails upon yond simple thief. Hark, in
thine ear: change places; and, handy-dandy, which
is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast seen
a farmer's dog bark at a beggar?

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Ay, sir.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: And the creature run from the cur? There thou
mightst behold the great image of authority: a
dog's obeyed in office.
Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand!
Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thine own back;
Thou hotly lust'st to use her in that kind
For which thou whipp'st her. The usurer hangs the cozener.
Through tatter'd clothes small vices do appear;
Robes and furr'd gowns hide all. Plate sin with gold,
And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks:
Arm it in rags, a pigmy's straw does pierce it.
None does offend, none, I say, none; I'll able 'em:
Take that of me, my friend, who have the power
To seal the accuser's lips. Get thee glass eyes;
And like a scurvy politician, seem
To see the things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now:
Pull off my boots: harder, harder: so.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: O, matter and impertinency mix'd! Reason in madness!

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
I know thee well enough; thy name is Gloucester:
Thou must be patient; we came crying hither:
Thou know'st, the first time that we smell the air,
We wawl and cry. I will preach to thee: mark.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Alack, alack the day!

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: When we are born, we cry that we are come
To this great stage of fools: this a good block;
It were a delicate stratagem, to shoe
A troop of horse with felt: I'll put 't in proof;
And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law,
Then, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: O, here he is: lay hand upon him. Sir,
Your most dear daughter--

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: No rescue? What, a prisoner? I am even
The natural fool of fortune. Use me well;
You shall have ransom. Let me have surgeons;
I am cut to the brains.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: You shall have any thing.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: No seconds? all myself?
Why, this would make a man a man of salt,
To use his eyes for garden water-pots,
Ay, and laying autumn's dust.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Good sir,--

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: I will die bravely, like a bridegroom. What!
I will be jovial: come, come; I am a king,
My masters, know you that.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: You are a royal one, and we obey you.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Then there's life in't. Nay, if you get it, you
shall get it with running. Sa, sa, sa, sa.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch,
Past speaking of in a king! Thou hast one daughter,
Who redeems nature from the general curse
Which twain have brought her to.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Hail, gentle sir.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Sir, speed you: what's your will?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Do you hear aught, sir, of a battle toward?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Most sure and vulgar: every one hears that,
Which can distinguish sound.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: But, by your favour,
How near's the other army?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Near and on speedy foot; the main descry
Stands on the hourly thought.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: I thank you, sir: that's all.

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Though that the queen on special cause is here,
Her army is moved on.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: I thank you, sir.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: You ever-gentle gods, take my breath from me:
Let not my worser spirit tempt me again
To die before you please!

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Well pray you, father.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Now, good sir, what are you?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: A most poor man, made tame to fortune's blows;
Who, by the art of known and feeling sorrows,
Am pregnant to good pity. Give me your hand,
I'll lead you to some biding.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Hearty thanks:
The bounty and the benison of heaven
To boot, and boot!

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: A proclaim'd prize! Most happy!
That eyeless head of thine was first framed flesh
To raise my fortunes. Thou old unhappy traitor,
Briefly thyself remember: the sword is out
That must destroy thee.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: Now let thy friendly hand
Put strength enough to't.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Wherefore, bold peasant,
Darest thou support a publish'd traitor? Hence;
Lest that the infection of his fortune take
Like hold on thee. Let go his arm.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Ch'ill not let go, zir, without vurther 'casion.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Let go, slave, or thou diest!

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Good gentleman, go your gait, and let poor volk
pass. An chud ha' bin zwaggered out of my life,
'twould not ha' bin zo long as 'tis by a vortnight.
Nay, come not near th' old man; keep out, che vor
ye, or ise try whether your costard or my ballow be
the harder: ch'ill be plain with you.

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Out, dunghill!

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Ch'ill pick your teeth, zir: come; no matter vor
your foins.

section.para: They fight, and EDGAR knocks him down

linegroup.speaker: OSWALD
linegroup.line: Slave, thou hast slain me: villain, take my purse:
If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body;
And give the letters which thou find'st about me
To Edmund earl of Gloucester; seek him out
Upon the British party: O, untimely death!

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: I know thee well: a serviceable villain;
As duteous to the vices of thy mistress
As badness would desire.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: What, is he dead?

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Sit you down, father; rest you
Let's see these pockets: the letters that he speaks of
May be my friends. He's dead; I am only sorry
He had no other death's-man. Let us see:
Leave, gentle wax; and, manners, blame us not:
To know our enemies' minds, we'ld rip their hearts;
Their papers, is more lawful.
'Let our reciprocal vows be remembered. You have
many opportunities to cut him off: if your will
want not, time and place will be fruitfully offered.
There is nothing done, if he return the conqueror:
then am I the prisoner, and his bed my goal; from
the loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supply
the place for your labour.
'Your--wife, so I would say--
'Affectionate servant,
'GONERIL.'
O undistinguish'd space of woman's will!
A plot upon her virtuous husband's life;
And the exchange my brother! Here, in the sands,
Thee I'll rake up, the post unsanctified
Of murderous lechers: and in the mature time
With this ungracious paper strike the sight
Of the death practised duke: for him 'tis well
That of thy death and business I can tell.

linegroup.speaker: GLOUCESTER
linegroup.line: The king is mad: how stiff is my vile sense,
That I stand up, and have ingenious feeling
Of my huge sorrows! Better I were distract:
So should my thoughts be sever'd from my griefs,
And woes by wrong imaginations lose
The knowledge of themselves.

linegroup.speaker: EDGAR
linegroup.line: Give me your hand:
Far off, methinks, I hear the beaten drum:
Come, father, I'll bestow you with a friend.

section.title: SCENE VII. A tent in the French camp. LEAR on a bed asleep, soft music playing; Gentleman, and others attending.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: O thou good Kent, how shall I live and work,
To match thy goodness? My life will be too short,
And every measure fail me.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: To be acknowledged, madam, is o'erpaid.
All my reports go with the modest truth;
Nor more nor clipp'd, but so.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: Be better suited:
These weeds are memories of those worser hours:
I prithee, put them off.

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Pardon me, dear madam;
Yet to be known shortens my made intent:
My boon I make it, that you know me not
Till time and I think meet.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: Then be't so, my good lord.
How does the king?

linegroup.speaker: Doctor
linegroup.line: Madam, sleeps still.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: O you kind gods,
Cure this great breach in his abused nature!
The untuned and jarring senses, O, wind up
Of this child-changed father!

linegroup.speaker: Doctor
linegroup.line: So please your majesty
That we may wake the king: he hath slept long.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: Be govern'd by your knowledge, and proceed
I' the sway of your own will. Is he array'd?

linegroup.speaker: Gentleman
linegroup.line: Ay, madam; in the heaviness of his sleep
We put fresh garments on him.

linegroup.speaker: Doctor
linegroup.line: Be by, good madam, when we do awake him;
I doubt not of his temperance.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: Very well.

linegroup.speaker: Doctor
linegroup.line: Please you, draw near. Louder the music there!

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: O my dear father! Restoration hang
Thy medicine on my lips; and let this kiss
Repair those violent harms that my two sisters
Have in thy reverence made!

linegroup.speaker: KENT
linegroup.line: Kind and dear princess!

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: Had you not been their father, these white flakes
Had challenged pity of them. Was this a face
To be opposed against the warring winds?
To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder?
In the most terrible and nimble stroke
Of quick, cross lightning? to watch--poor perdu!--
With this thin helm? Mine enemy's dog,
Though he had bit me, should have stood that night
Against my fire; and wast thou fain, poor father,
To hovel thee with swine, and rogues forlorn,
In short and musty straw? Alack, alack!
'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all. He wakes; speak to him.

linegroup.speaker: Doctor
linegroup.line: Madam, do you; 'tis fittest.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: How does my royal lord? How fares your majesty?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: You do me wrong to take me out o' the grave:
Thou art a soul in bliss; but I am bound
Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears
Do scald like moulten lead.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: Sir, do you know me?

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: You are a spirit, I know: when did you die?

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: Still, still, far wide!

linegroup.speaker: Doctor
linegroup.line: He's scarce awake: let him alone awhile.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Where have I been? Where am I? Fair daylight?
I am mightily abused. I should e'en die with pity,
To see another thus. I know not what to say.
I will not swear these are my hands: let's see;
I feel this pin prick. Would I were assured
Of my condition!

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
linegroup.line: O, look upon me, sir,
And hold your hands in benediction o'er me:
No, sir, you must not kneel.

linegroup.speaker: KING LEAR
linegroup.line: Pray, do not mock me:
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less;
And, to deal plainly,
I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
Methinks I should know you, and know this man;
Yet I am doubtful for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is; and all the skill I have
Remembers not these garments; nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me;
For, as I am a man, I think this lady
To be my child Cordelia.

linegroup.speaker: CORDELIA
